On 8 Aug 2018, at 10:41 pm, <shelly@shellyhorton.com> <shelly@shellyhorton.com> wrote:


Hi guys,

Three major edits to be done as soon as possible please…

1. The privacy policy page gives an error message. https://shellshockedmedia.com/privacy-policy__trashed/ Can you please fix this? Is there a standard privacy policy?

2. Chapter 7 Challenge – Just do it - the transcript is missing

Please add

CHALLENGE

You’ve probably already put two and two together and figured out that my challenge for you this chapter is to jump in front of the camera.

If this is completely new to you, then start with something small like a live video on Instagram, Snapchat or Facebook that doesn’t need any editing.

If you’re a little more game, why not script and film a video and send it to family or friends for feedback?

But please, when you’re watching yourself back, be critical but don’t pick yourself apart.

The only way to make engaging, really great videos, is to start off making some not-so-great ones.

The more you make, the more comfortable you’ll become on screen.

3. Chapter 8 Pep talk – You’ve got this! transcript is missing – please add

Congratulations! You’ve finished my media and presentation course! Yay you! So, I just wanted to recap some of the lessons for you. Remember you can go back and re-do the chapters at any time.

I strongly advise you do the voice lessons and facial warm ups every single time before you present to camera or do a media interview. It’s like getting on your game face.

And listen to my free MP3 of the Nerve Busting Breathing Exercise. Just press play and I’ll guide you through the exercise to help calm your nerves.

Check out your pics of presenting outfits so you remember what to wear. Dress to suit the image you want to project. And remember bright block colours work best. You want to pop on screen.

Remember never say no to make up, and that includes the fellas, because studio lights can make you look like the walking dead

Spend some time working out your key messages. The basics of every interview comes down to Who What Where When Why How.

Don’t write it out in full and memorise it. Reduce each key message to three dot points.

Keep in mind great story telling involves sharing anecdotes. Tell a story, paint pictures with your words and people will remember your message.

Never forget my life motto - the 5Ps – Prior Preparation Prevents Piss-poor Performance. If you’ve done the hard work and prepared properly you will perform well.

Be aware of your body language. You need to be in control of everything from your facial expressions to your gestures because the things we don't say, can still say so much.

Keep eye contact, if you look away you look untrustworthy. Use that trick I taught you about looking between the eyebrows. It really works and no-one will ever know.

Know the show you are going to appear on and the audience. Set the TV to record the shows you may appear on so you know their presenters and their style.

NEVER, ever, EVER say “No Comment”. If you are dealing with tricky or negative questions just answer honestly and as positively as possible.

Prepare for some negative feedback. Time you get some thick skin.

If you are presenting straight to camera look through the lens, not atthe lens, as it helps you connect with people watching.

It’s also important to realise people want you to succeed.

Your audiencewants you to be interesting, stimulating, informative and entertaining. They’re rooting for you. They’re not there hoping you do a crap job in telling your story.

And finally… Enjoyit. Remember your WHY? You’ve worked hard to get to where you are and you wanted to get this exposure. Remember your initial passion and try to have fun. After all, if you’re having fun people will enjoy watching you.


Now because you have finished this course you are now part of the alumni and I’ve got some awesome offers for you.


If you would like to top up this course with some one-on-one training with me you’ll get it at a discount.


Plus, if you are not based in Sydney I am also available for Skype consultations. Where we can choose to work on your key messages to make sure they are exactly right. Or you can send me iPhone clips of your presenting and I will assess them over Skype and suggest ways you can improve.


I’ll also have some add-on courses coming soon including:

- How to be a great MC

- Presenting the perfect key note speech

- How to moderate a panel


So, watch your inbox for new tips and tricks. Or email me via the contact page if want some more information. I’m Shelly Horton and it’s been a pleasure teaching you. I can’t wait to see you shine on camera.


Shelly Horton

0404 868 463

shellshockedmedia.com
